newsitem.title: USA: INSIGHT -- Dlr must clear hurdles before more gains.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT -- Dlr must clear hurdles before more gains.

text.p: Dollar/mark needs to close at 1.4960 marks or higher before it can extend gains posted after Germany cut its repo rate by 30 basis points, analysts said.

A close of at least 1.4960 marks would put the dollar on track for a rise to 1.5070 and possibly 1.5130, while failure to close around that level would open the way for a retracment to 1.4860 marks or lower, they said.

"In my opinion (1.4960 marks) is a big swing level. If we can close above 1.4960 I think we can have about another 80 to 100 points on the upside," said Ture Johnson, technical analyst at Bank of America.
Analysts see the dollar in a 1.4860-1.4980 mark range over the next 24 hours, with key supports at 1.4900 and 1. and resistance at 1.4960 and 1.5000 marks.

"As far as dollar/mark goes, I feel if we don't see some follow-through buying pretty quickly, we're going to see a little correction," Cynthia Cooley, foreign exchange analyst at United Gulf Bank of Bahrain, said.
"The bottom of that correction is probably 1.4860 (marks). I think there's probably some interim support at 1.4900."
MMS International, in its written commentary, noted that 1.4960 was a 38.2 percent retracement from the May-July drop.
Dollar/yen is more decidedly bullish but it must overcome hurdles at 108.60 and 108.80 yen, analysts said.

"I feel relatively bullish on dollar/yen but there's a little bit of a battleground. 108.80 is the next resistance above 108.60. It may come off 108.80 to 108.40. There may be some residual drag if dollar/mark comes off," Cooley said.
Johnson expects the U.S. currency to test resistance at 108.80 yen in the near term. A break above that level would clear the way for a move to 109.70-110.00 yen, he said.
Analysts see dollar/yen in a near-term range of 108.10-108.80 yen, with a possible extension to 109.00.
"I would think we'll hold 108.20 yen, so I would say you should take a shot at buying (dollars) ahead of 108.20 with a stop below 108.00," Johnson said.
Mark/yen, meanwhile, is seen stuck in a 72.30-73.30 yen range. 73.30 has proved tough resistance, analysts said.
Cooley noted that mark/yen has been making progressively lower tops and lower lows since July.
"I'm looking for mark/yen to experience a nice correction," she said. "I would say it's going to see in the short-term at least 72.20. Then I think 71.80 is going to provide some decent support."
